channel.title: A New Chapter for Cross Platform TFS
channel.description: Four years ago this month, I joined a small start-up being created called Teamprise after reading about it on Eric Sink's blog. Our mission was to bring the benefits of application lifecycle management (ALM) with Microsoft Team Foundation Server to...
channel.dc:creator: Martin

item.title: Comment by Gal Granov+00:00
item.description:
Martin,
great news.
u deserve this. i hope there is a lot of $$$ in it also :)
great!
item.dc:creator: Gal Granov

item.title: Comment by sholdsworth+00:00
item.description:
Congrats Martin!
Don't let the big blue machine crush your Java & Eclipse love too much :)!
Best of luck with the new role!
item.dc:creator: sholdsworth

item.title: Comment by Pedro Pombeiro+00:00
item.description:
What an exciting announcement! Congratulations Martin, this is an acknowledgment on the great work you guys have been doing!
I wish all the best for your new role.
item.dc:creator: Pedro Pombeiro

item.title: Comment by Rob Burke+00:00
item.description: Brilliant news. Congrats to you Martin.

item.title: Comment by Rob Say+00:00
item.description:
Now there's turn up for the books.. Congratulations - nice move, Carpe diem all that! I can see the grin from here.
Washington is a nice place - get some time off if/when you get out there.
item.dc:creator: Rob Say

item.title: Comment by AP+00:00
item.description:
I have a theory of where this is going. Let's see if you prove me wrong:
1. Embrace: have a solution that offers cross-platform bug-tracking and version-control, so people would start using Microsoft tools
2. Extend: In the following versions, Windows clients would work better and support more features than non-Windows clients, so people would pay buy Windows instead of other platforms
3. Extinguish: kill support for cross-platform altogether - only Windows clients would be supported
item.dc:creator: AP

item.title: Comment by Martin Woodward+00:00
item.dc:creator: Martin Woodward
